Your explanation would fail for a hydrofoil moving slowly through liquid helium. You did a good job explaining the wrong misconception. But it is sad that you did not go the WHOLE stretch to explain the lift which is caused mainly by an underpressure at the upper surface and a slight overpressure at the lower surface of the wing. You also missed out on explaining WHY the air along the upper surface accelerates in such a way that it arrives at the trailing edge of the wing before the air passing along the lower surface. You also failed to correct the taught misconseptions of Bernoulli's law when it is applied to some "false physics teachers" when they try to explain a wing's lift. The main misconception in "Bernoulli" is cause and effect. The low pressure along the upper surface of the wing is the cause of the acceleration of the airflow. It's NOT that the faster flowing air is generating a lower pressure.
Now it remains only to explain why there is a low pressure at the upper surface of the wing. The explanation is smple according Newton: The fluid air tends to travel at a staight line if not acted upon by a perpendicular force. The curved flow of air is like in any other curved motion of a mass: It's acted upon by centripetal force. The upper wing surface has to supply this centripetal force to make the airflow follow the curve (wing shape). This "pulling down" of the airstream around the curve causes a lower pressure at the inside of the curve compared to the outside of the curve. (Like in a centrifuge). If you would add some of these thoughts, your video would fully live up to its title.

So air moves over and around the plane as it flies. (You already understand this, when you put your hand out of the window of a moving car, it’s the same thing.)

As that air moves along the back-end of the wing, (the air is sticking to the wing, and moving along with the shape of the wing.) The air is then pushed downward because of the shape of the wing. Almost correct... The air going faster over the wing than under it DOES NOT CAUSE lower pressure... the lower pressure above the wing causes the air to accelerate into it, and decelerate as it leaves the lower pressure region. The Bernoulli equation does NOT say faster air causes lower pressure, it says they will co-exist. It is self evident that air will accelerate into a lower pressure region... The opposite is NOT true... The air being accelerated downward by the curved wing shape causes the lower pressure above, and increased pressure below the wing. These pressures cause the air above and below to accelerate and decelerate etc.

Why is this still a debate? Whether you compute Bernoulli's principle, finite element analysis (aka "blade theory"), or impulse (downward acceleration of the fluid air) ALL produce precisely the same result, lift+drag, and can be equated through their respective equations.

A flat blade deflects airflow quite well. The reason we use airfoils is because they're far more efficient at deflecting the flow of air than a flat blade, which induces a lot of energy-robbing flow separation and turbulence. By the way, induced drag is nothing more than the x-component of the resultant force, while lift is the y-component. Add them up and reverse the sign to see what happened to the undisturbed air mass after the passing airfoil disturbs it. Essentially, it's accelerated mostly downward (opposite of lift), but also a bit forward (opposite of induced drag).

Attempting to answer how a wing can fly upside down. What isn't considered in this video is the importance of keeping the airflow attached to the surface of the wing. There is a critical angle of attack to the oncoming air. If the angle is increased further the air flowing over the upper surface detaches, becomes turbulent, and drag increases resulting in a "stall". Wings designed to fly inverted also have a curved bottom surface which keeps the airflow attached. This is a symmetrical airfoil. ( or semi-symmetrical )
It is possible to fly a flat bottomed wing inverted at a high angle of attack, BUT keeping the airflow attached with a flat bottomed wing at a high angle can only happen in a narrow Speed/angle configuration.

Bernoulli is a simplified version of a much more complicated set of differential equations (D.E.'s) that describe the movement of a fluid. One of the assumptions made in simplifying these D.E.'s is to assume that air is inviscid (no viscosity). As strange as it sounds, if a fluid has no viscosity, it is IMPOSSIBLE for it to impart a force to an object submerged in the flow (in steady state analysis anyway).
There's other assumptions that rule out using Bernoulli's Principle in this analysis, but even if it weren't for any of these, there are other factors that affect the pressure of a fluid. Bernoulli only explains that components of pressure that results from movement of a fluid ALONG A STREAMLINE. Pressure can be imparted onto a fluid from other parcels of fluid that aren't on the same streamline, however (check out pressure gradients resulting from curved streamlines).

In fact, Bernoulli's princip only applies to in-compressible fluids like liquids... ( But can be used for gases up to Mach 0.3)
- With compressible fluids like gases, the process is not Isothermal, and the energy will be converted from heat to velocity and back as the pressure rises and falls... - That's why wings on a supersonic jet fighter almost have no lift due to this princip :)

I don't think you need to deflect air down. The flow just needs to be curved by inserting something into it. Foils with high angles of attack deflect down, but it's the relative curvature of the flow that matters, and the separation of the different flows across the bottom and the top. Symmetrical foils need an angle of attack, asymmetric ones dont. Your flat bottomed foil can generate lift when the bottom of the foil is parallel to the airflow. To generate lift upside down, it needs a different angle of attack. The air does not need to be deflected down, just curved as it passes by the wing. Shortly after the wing, the air is happily sitting as it was before the wing passed through it.
Curved flows have pressure gradients across them (lower towards the inside) - as explained by f=ma (and Bernoulli - which applies to each streamline). The flow on the top of a wing therefore has lower than atmospheric pressure at the wing surface, and the flow across the bottom has higher (or a flat bottom wing has nearly atmospheric pressure and there is no curvature in the lower flow field). Low pressure on top, high on bottom == lift. It's just why that is the case that confuses most people.

Sorry, but still partly wrong. It is generally accepted that Bernoullis equation says faster air causes a lower pressure... it doesnt say that, and it isn't true. It says they will co-exist. Consider a very long box sealed in the middle. high pressure one end and low pressure the other end. Now abruptly remove the seal. High pressure air will rush into the low pressure region... F=MA. Always true, and in this case, Pressure difference gradient =  Fluid density x Acceleration. So, it is absolutely clear that lower pressure above the wing is WHY the air in front of it rushes toward the lowest pressure region... and is then moving faster. then as it approaches the rear, where the pressure is higher, it slows down again. If A causes B, and B causes A, then we get a chain reaction... We do not get a chain reaction and air WILL accelerate into a lower pressure region, therefore it is impossible for the increase in speed to be the cause of the lower pressure. You are right about the coanda effect being the reason that the air follows the upper surface downward... this needs more explanation.  ALL of the lift (F) is the result of Air with mass (M) being accelerated downward. For a plane up in the sky, there is absolutely nothing to provide a force upward other than by accelerating the mass of air downward... So the Newtonian explanation although usually incomplete (as it is here) is the only correct one.

"so that both streams meet up simultaneously at the trailing edge" is a common misconception about lift. If this portion of the theory were true, you'd need a substantially (unsustainably) higher angle of attack to produce the necessary differential in pressure (ie lift) to actually create a useful force. It's called the "equal path" or "equal transit" theory. https://www.grc.nasa.gov/WWW/K-12/airplane/wrong1.html

I think that answer is a bit general... In particular:
The answer is CENTRIFUGAL FORCE, because airflow at the top of the wing has to turn rapidly when it reaches max camber, and the force required to make that change in direction is a centripetal force actuated in the mass of air. Because of Newton's 3rd law (one force actuates in conjunction with another one, with same direction and intensity, however different way) there is another, centrifugal force, that actuates on the wing. This force is, in most part, the source for lift. This theory explains the fact why airplanes DO fly inverted, as long as they fly with a positive angle of attack in relation to the ground... There is a number of ways to increase lift (in many cases, the lift coefficient L=0.5*rho*V^2*A*C_L):
-Increase speed, because the centripetal force and centrifugal force will be greater;
-Increase the density of the mass of air (basically, fly lower and in colder temperatures);
-use high-lift devices such as flaps and slats, which increase the curvature of the wing, although creating more drag;
-increase the curvature of the wing profile itself;
-etc

I think there is still one missing piece even from the most precise "macro" description of lift. The 6 sided force cube on a streamline is a good explanation but students are still baffled by why air has low pressure when it moves at higher relative velocity, i..e why do stream lines curve from high to low pressure.

The analogy of why is your friend is travelling on a bus and reaches out to grab your hands while you are on roller blades. You feel a pulling force until their momentum overcomes your grip. If thousands of friends are passing by in the bus each grabbing your hand momentarily, you will feel a pretty constant force pulling on you. If you are sticking to a wing you in turn are going to pull on it, while air underneath will push.
Above the leading edge where air expands rapidly from thrust compression, the wing is experiencing a strong pulling force, which is why gyros, and helicopters autorotate, conventional elevators resist this torque, and canards neutralize the torque.

The boundary layer is layers of people moving faster and faster away from the wing in fact within the layer air can go faster than the relative speed of the entire aircraft body.
This is why modern passenger aircraft have supercritical wings because conventional wings would accelerate air beyond Mach in level flight forming shock waves that would cause rapid loss of lift. Aircraft around 0.83 to Mach 1.
When a wing disturbs the boundary layer these pulling forces are lost and a stall occurs.

If I say 'centrifugal force' everyone will get very upset because the acutal force is not centrifugal, the force is centripetal, the reaction is centrifugal. However, if I say 'lift force' nobody has a problem... except I do, you should too! Lift is a reaction, an equibrant of the force that an aerofoil imparts onto the air. To be even more precise, lift is a vector component of the total reaction of an aerofoil interacting with the air.

The aerofoil has kinetic energy, it imparts that energy onto the air; the force is generated by the aerofoil interacting with the air as it moves through it. This video describes the air having kinetic energy and acting on the aerofoil, which is incorrect unless you are in a wind tunnel. The force is produced by the aerofoil moving through the air and it has an equal and opposite reaction, the total reaction, the 'vertical' vector component of the total reaction we call lift (although, lift may not always act vertically - another simplification, I'm not going there today). This is never described very well in any text book, it is always "simplified" to the point that it doesn't describe reality and causes unnecessary confusion.

There is a fundamental issue with this explanation and that is the assumption that the Bernoulli theorem (and it is simply a mathematical construct that describes a physical phenomenon) "causes" the lift.  No, it does not cause the lift.  In a dynamically closed system, a fluid moving into a region of lower pressure must accelerate because it is moving down a pressure gradient.  Thus, each fluid parcel is experiencing an unbalanced force, but its resistance to that acceleration "pushes back" at the higher pressure, maintaining that pressure gradient.  

Now, when the air passes under the wing, the streamlines of fluid parcels are deflected downwards.  This is because the underside of the wing directly deflects the adjacent fluid parcels downward.  These exert a pressure on incoming parcels that causes them to slow down (accelerate in a forward direction, or against the direction of flow).  Their resistance to this acceleration generates the pressure gradient under the wing and the pressure gradient generates the acceleration.  Reciprocal cause and effect.  Most people can intuitively understand why the air passing under the wing must be deflected downwards and why it must slow down.

However, the "cloud" of increased pressure under the wing also extends slightly forward of the wing, as well.  Fluid parcels approaching the leading edge that are destined to pass over the wing are initially deflected upwards by that "cloud" of increased pressure extending below and in front of the wing.  As they pass over the leading edge and top side of the wing, the individual air molecules would continue in a straight line up and back, but air is a fluid and collisions between air molecules are common.  Thus, the air that has been deflected upwards is now being forced by the air above it to accelerate back downwards to follow the contour of the upper surface of the wing.  That air's inertial resistance to that downward acceleration causes it to form a "bubble" of low pressure above the wing and that same "bubble" of low pressure causes the acceleration that the air's inertia resists.  Again, reciprocal cause-and-effect.  

The Bernoulli theorem is a mathematical construct that describes the way that fluid parcels must accelerate as they move from high to low pressure (and vice-versa), but it does not, in and of itself, explain why

This seems like an incomplete explanation, and it doesn't describe Bernoulli's principle adequately. Bernoulli's principle never says why the air speeds up, just that it does so with an associated decrease in pressure. In the case of a wing, the air speeds up because it in a sense passes through a restriction created by the camber of the wing, like in a venturi. Visualized two dimensionally, the camber of the wing forms the bottom of the restriction, and the airflow not affected by the wing forms the top. This explains why a cambered wing creates lift even at zero angle of attack. In fact, camber has such a profound effect on the performance of a wing, that certain extremely thick and highly cambered wings can offset some of their induced drag by creating a lift vector angled towards the direction of flight.

I also feel that the video oversimplifies what happens when the angle of attack increases, only addressing the increase in Newtonian lift, the downward deflection of air. Increasing the angle of attack also decreases the size of the theoretical restriction, thus speeding up the airflow over the top of the wing. This explains how a flat wing like the Wright Brothers' was able to fly. Camber is not needed to induce Bernoullian lift when the angle of attack is anything but zero.

Overall I think that this explanation is pointed in the right direction, but it's still inadequate to the point that it unfortunately further contributes to an improper understanding of lift. It correctly addresses the misconception that two air-streams separated at the leading edge must meet at the trailing edge, and it introduces little known Newtonian lift, but it really is a vast oversimplification and gross under-explanation of the contributions of Bernoullian lift. Yes they both exist in wing aerodynamics and are complexly interrelated, but they don't explain the same thing.

Here is the interesting thing about the Newtonian, physical, explanation: Gravity actually provides two-thirds to three-quarters of the energy needed to sustain lift. The energy from the engines is used to overcome drag and then to create additional lift for level or rising flight beyond what the energy from gravity is producing.

One can compute the needed BTUs to create lift equal to a plane's weight, ignoring drag, and will find that that number is substantially greater than the BTUs in a plane's carried fuel.

Now be nice, as I know it’s hard to believe, but if a plane is transferring energy to airflow in such a way as to support it, then in any one instance, the energy transfer must equal what would be needed to support the airplane if it only had vertically mounted rockets.

A 747 weighs about 735,000lbs. at takeoff, yet it’s 4 engines only provide about 200,000lbs. of thrust. That means that, less drag, the engines provide about one-quarter of the needed energy transfer to create and sustain lift. Gravity in conjunction with the glide-slope of the plane and gravity provide the rest.

Mostly a good explanation but the upper surface air IS NOT caused by the Coanda effect.  Coanda LIFT is caused by artificially accelerated air such as with Upper Surface Blowing. In effect Coanda lift simply increases the airspeed that is being bent downwards and this increased speed gives additional lift at low airspeeds.

Also please also note that the air on top of the wing DOES NOT accelerate in a chord-wise way as is often stated.

If you look at the streamlines video you can see that the upper surface air is actually being pulled forwards with the wing  due to form drag and viscosity. (look at the reference lines out of the influence of the wing.

The Upper Surface air is only travelling faster in relation to the lower surface air.

In reality the air is not moving at all, the wing is. The wing pushes the lower surface air downwards and forwards creating a bow wave and this creates lift.The Upper Surface air MUST follow the upper surface as you can't have a vacuum in normal space. As the upper surface air turns the corner it spreads out and the density drops. This combined with the change of  direction adds to lift.

The pressure differential between the upper and lower surfaces is primarily caused by AOA NOT wing shape. As shown earlier, flat plates generate plenty of lift with little drag. (make a paper plane and fly it if you are not sure.)

Put simply Bernoulli describes WHAT is happening (pressure differentials) but Newton describes WHY (turning flow,) Again the pressure differentials as caused by AOA so AOA is responsible for lift. Period.

The more air that is bent downwards, and the greater the angle of change, the more lift. That is why flaps (particularly Fowler flaps) increase lift. Stick your hand out of a car window while you are driving along, incline it to the relative Airflow and you will experience lift. Or you could just sit under a ceiling fan and enjoy the breeze. Same effect.

I don't think that is quite right.   An asymmetrical airfoil will not generate lift unless it has an angle of attack.   The air hitting the upper face will deflect the wing downward.
The far greater effect is just from forcing air down while moving forward at an angle of attack, which from Newton means the wing is pushed in an equal and opposite direction while doing so.  
Thus symmetrical wings fly perfectly well.  Fancy airfoils are about reducing drag at particular angles of attack.

These are not two different ways of talking about the same thing, they are two different effects.   It seems likely that the angle of attack and Newtons laws account for the far larger effect.   The curved upper surface of the wing plays a greater role minimizing the tendency of the air to break free from the wing and causing turbulent air causing excessive drag.   You could have a perfectly flat wing but it would most likely be very hard to trim and prone to stalling without warning.

Actually, a little bit of memory jogging and googling brings it back: Lift is due to the magnus effect (L =  ρ(V^K) with K = the path integral around a closed loop in the velocity field). Wings are designed such that there is circulation at the trailing edge, The circulation gives rise to lift as per the magnus effect. Since a circulation axis has to form a closed loop, this also explains the vortices in the wake of an aircraft. A lot of vector calculus and headaches, arguably not worth it :P

No, the total lift is not a summation of both Bernouli lift and Newton Lift. Rather, Bernouli is just a way of deriving the lift from physically measurable quantities (pressure distribution over the airfoil, airspeed, angle of attack and such), where Newtonian physics is the underlying principle that accounts for what actually happens in reality (though, Newton is wrong in the sense that relativity and QM "correct" Newton for high speed or small size effects)

It is due to the Coanda effect, which is caused by entrainment. Essentially, a streamline passing over the top of the wing entrans air creating a region of low pressure directly above the wing. This creates a pressure gradient over the wing that pushes the streamline down and causes it to follow the curvature of the wing (this is the Coanda effect). The force from the pressure gradient not only changes the direction of the streamline but it also increases the speed of the streamline.

Rectangle wings are used on smaller slow moving craft

Bernoulli is partly right when it comes to wings, but his equations were originally worked out for dealing with things like trains passing each other and why they lean towards each other as they do. His equations were used to determine how close together rail tracks could be and let trains safely pass each other without tipping into each other. When applied to an airfoil, the equations have a bad assumption, but that doesn't negate them, just means the assumption needs to be adjusted.

If you sum the pressures over the top and bottom of the wing, you will get the net force on the wing (which is equal and opposite to the net force on the air). If a wing didn't deflect the air their would be no pressure difference, and if there were no pressure difference, the air wouldn't deflect.

There is no unaffected air above the wing.  All of the air above the wing is affected to an infinite height.  Only at infinity does the velocity of the air equal the stream velocity (velocity of the air approaching the wing).  Usually you define a region above the wing in which the air is significantly affected.  The upper bound is called the boundary layer where the velocity of the air is about 98% of the free stream velocity.  Lift is calculated by conservation of momentum of a control volume
